name: Dream Journal
summary: The practice of recording dreams immediately upon waking to improve dream recall, self-awareness, and creative insight.
explanation:
A dream journal is a dedicated notebook or digital document kept beside your bed for the purpose of recording dreams as soon as you wake up. Because dream memories fade rapidly — often within minutes of waking — immediacy is critical to capturing the details, emotions, and narrative threads of your dreams.

The practice offers several benefits. For creativity, dreams provide a rich source of novel associations and imagery that the waking mind rarely produces. Many artists, writers, and scientists have credited dreams with inspiring breakthroughs. For self-understanding, recurring dream themes and symbols can reveal underlying concerns, desires, and emotional patterns that may not be fully conscious. For those interested in lucid dreaming, a dream journal is considered an essential foundation, as improved dream recall is the first step toward recognizing when you are dreaming.

Practical tips for maintaining a dream journal include: keep it within arm's reach of your bed, write immediately upon waking before doing anything else, capture emotions and sensory details alongside the narrative, note any recurring themes or symbols, and avoid judging or analyzing entries while writing — simply record what you remember.

Over time, reviewing your dream journal entries can reveal patterns and recurring motifs. Research on dream recall suggests that the simple act of intending to remember your dreams and having a recording practice significantly increases the number and vividness of dreams you can recall, creating a positive feedback loop between attention and memory.
